div.p: I received in Washington the very interesting letter you wrote me on hearing that I was going to the Pacific. I have been so hurried since then that I have not had time to send you a reply; and even now I have time to say only a few words, hoping to be able to write you a long letter before I take my final departure. You have no idea how lonely I felt in Wash, contrasting as I did the dullness then prevalencewith the merry time we had last winter. I stopped at the national, but was several times at Brown's; new faces met me at every turn; Nash. seemed like another place. I suppose you have heard of Miss Toomb's marriage to a Sen Alexander; I was invited but could not go. Mr and Mrs Pendleton are in the same house that I am here: Mrs Pendleton doesnot look very well. Mr. Mrs. & Miss Bass are here. I have seen Mrs B. but have not yet made Miss B's acquaintance. I leave here about Wednesday next. After then no letters will reach me this side of the Mountains. I do up the

Missouri River about 2000 miles in a steamer & then by land across the Rocky Mountains to the Columbia River, and then down that River to its mouth, and I shall be disappointed if I do not get back in less than a year. My address on the other side will be to the care of the Quarter Master U.S.A. Columbia Barrack oregon Territory. Do write me often and fully and freely; tell the Col. to write me; and sister Rachel must write me there; why doesnot she write me now; I wrote her from Mess Pouir, and she ought to have answered. Send me newspapers, I shall be greedy for news when I get to the Columbia River. Begin to send me this to the above address about the 1st of July. I am just called off, so must close. Give my love to the Col. and all at home. I have just written to Pa.
